channel.title: Detect Package
channel.description: Is there a method or a class anywhere for finding where a class is located, with nothing more than the name of the class. For example I know the name of a class is 'Integer' however I need to get the package in which this class is, without looking it up manually, or iterating over every package until it's found.

item.title: Detect Package
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:16, topic:338323”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=434712.msg3192389#msg3192389 date=1272404243]
what happened to Class.forName?
[/quote]
That requires package. Loading something like Integer would require Class.forName(“java.lang.Integer”).[/quote]

I told you a work around:

[code]public String findPackage(String class) {
String[] packageNames = { “java.lang.”, “java.awt.” … };

for(String package : packageNames) {
try {
Class.forName(package + className);
return package + className;
} catch(ClassNotFoundException e) {
// Wasn’t it.
}
}
}[/code] Also be sure to have the custom classes they may need like say you have an IRC library “IrcLibrary.jar”

java -cp IrcLibrary.jar MyClassFinder

So then Class.forName will be able to find the IRC library’s classes.

One way you could improve what I said, would be to make it load custom package names from a file, and keep the default packages in the array hardcoded

Read full topic

item.title: Detect Package
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Evil_:

One way you could improve what I said, would be to make it load custom package names from a file, and keep the default packages in the array hardcoded

Package.getPackages(). Limited ofcourse to your ClassLoader… which Class.forName() is limited to anyway. Remember to check the default “” package as well.

Use Instrumentation.getAllLoadedClasses() if you want all classes.

Read full topic

item.title: Detect Package
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

frank_:

you could always insert the contents of included packages into a map of simple name -> qualified name

[quote=“oksuper_, post:12, topic:338323”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=434712.msg3192369#msg3192369 date=1272403040]
you could always insert the contents of included packages into a map of simple name -> qualified name
[/quote]
personally i would do simple name -> potential qualified names[/quote]
although that is a better alternative, there’s no PROPER way of listing all classes within a package

Read full topic

item.title: Detect Package
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:6, topic:338323”][quote author=Evil_ link=topic=434712.msg3192330#msg3192330 date=1272401358]

you can use the instrumentation api to see all loaded classes (that way you don’t have to iterate through all packages) and just find the ones matching the relative class name

edit: unless, of course, it’s not within your classpath - then the search would just be entirely redundant
[/quote]So then, we’re back to square one lol. It sounds as if he’s trying to make something like an auto-complete feature of sorts.

But, I’m pretty sure even if there was a function, it’d just iterate over the packages, which he says he doesn’t want to do.

Well, I sided against iteration due to performance issues, but if that’s the /only/ way then…

and Abraham2119:
The class name would be taken from user input, and then I need to find the package of the class name (if the class exists) and then take a field value from the class. The class could be anything from something in the default package, to one of my own classes.[/quote]In that case you’d have to specify your packages, like…directories or something, I’m kinda sure you could do something like this… (not tested)

public String findPackage(String class) {
String[] packageNames = { "java.lang.", "java.awt." ... };

for(String package : packageNames) {
    try {
        Class.forName(package + className);
        return package + className;
    } catch(ClassNotFoundException e) {
        // Wasn't it.
    }
}
}

Read full topic

item.title: Detect Package
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Evil_, post:5, topic:338323”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=434712.msg3192323#msg3192323 date=1272400968]
you can use the instrumentation api to see all loaded classes (that way you don’t have to iterate through all packages) and just find the ones matching the relative class name

edit: unless, of course, it’s not within your classpath - then the search would just be entirely redundant
[/quote]So then, we’re back to square one lol. It sounds as if he’s trying to make something like an auto-complete feature of sorts.

But, I’m pretty sure even if there was a function, it’d just iterate over the packages, which he says he doesn’t want to do.[/quote]

Well, I sided against iteration due to performance issues, but if that’s the /only/ way then…

and Abraham2119:
The class name would be taken from user input, and then I need to find the package of the class name (if the class exists) and then take a field value from the class. The class could be anything from something in the default package, to one of my own classes.

Read full topic
